Stat 101 1 Introduction These notes are forâ€¦ 1.1 About number sets \(\mathbb{N}\): Set of natural numbers. \(\mathbb{R}\): Set of real numbers. For any natural number \(n\) (in symbols: \(\forall n \in \mathbb{N}\)), \(\mathbb{R}^n\): Set of \(n\)-tuples of real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\). It is usually called \(n\)-dimensional real space. The elements of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) are written \((x_{1},x_{2},\ldots ,x_{n})\), where each \(x_{i}\) is a real number. Example: For \(n=2\), the elements of \(\mathbb{R}^2\) are written \((x_{1},x_{2})\) and usually visualized on a Cartesian plane. [img] 1.2 About functions A function describes the relation between two sets. T 1.3 About norms (In the context of Statistical Learning) A norm is a function from the \(n\)-dimensional real space to the non-negative real numbers, in symbols: \[\ell: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\geq0}\] This function is intrinsically related to the concept of distance. It is usually denoted by enclosing within double vertical lines, if \(x \in \mathbb{R}^n\) then the norm of \(x\) is represented by: \(||x||\). 1.4 Linear Regression
